sen.e: The enshrined deity is Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto Hime-gami.

The chronicle of the founding of the shrine and the enshrinement of the deities are unknown.

sen.j: 社格式内社（名神大）県社
sen.e: The shrine ranking is Shikinai-sha (Myojin Taisha), a prefectural shrine.
The shrine ranks as a Shikinai-sha (Myojin Taisha), a prefectural shrine.

sen.j: 水尾神社（みをじんじゃ）は滋賀県高島市にある神社である。
sen.e: Mio Jinja Shrine is located in Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 創祀年代不詳であるが、式内社で年4度の奉幣のほか名神大社として臨時大祭にも奉幣があった。
sen.e: The first enshrinement date is unknown, however, hohei (offering a wand with hemp and paper streamers to a Shinto god) were conducted not only four times a year at Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws), but also at extraordinary festivals of Myojin-taisha Shrine.

The first enshrinement date is unknown, however, hohei (offering a wand with hemp and paper streamers to a Shinto god) were conducted not only four times a year at Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws), but also during extraordinary festivals of Myojin-taisha Shrine.

The first enshrinement date is unknown, however, hohei (offering a wand with hemp and paper streamers to a Shinto god) were conducted not only four times a year at Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws), but also during extraordinary festivals of Myojin-taisha Shrine.

sen.j: 延暦3年（784年）従五位下、貞観 (日本)5年（863年）従四位下の神階を授けられ、明治15年（1882年）に郷社、大正4年（1915年）に県社に列格した。
sen.e: The shrine was given the divine rank of Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade in 784 and the divine rank of Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade in 863, then designated as a gosha (a village shrine) in 1882 and a prefectural shrine in 1915.

The shrine was given the divine rank of Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade in 784 and the divine rank of Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade in 863, then designated as a gosha (a village shrine) in 1882 and a prefectural shrine in 1915.

The shrine was given the divine rank of Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade in 784 and the divine rank of Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade in 863, then designated as a gosha (a village shrine) in 1882 and a prefectural shrine in 1915.

sen.j: 磐衝別命は猿田彦の天成神道を学ぶため当地に来住し、朝夕猿田彦命を祀る三尾大明神を遙拝されたのでこの地を拜戸と言うようになったと伝わる。
sen.e: It has been said that this place came to be called Haido since Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto came to the place to learn Amenaru-Michi (Way of Heaven) conveyed by Sarutahiko (Shinto god) and he worshipped in the morning and evening from afar Mio Daimyojin deity which enshrined Sarutahiko no mikoto.

It has been said that this place came to be called Haido since Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto came to the place to learn Amenaru-Michi (Way of Heaven) conveyed by Sarutahiko (Shinto god) and he worshipped in the morning and evening from afar Mio Daimyojin deity which enshrined Sarutahiko no mikoto.

It has been said that this place came to be called Haido since Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto came to the place to learn Amenaru-Michi (Way of Heaven) conveyed by Sarutahiko (Shinto god) and he worshipped in the morning and evening from afar Mio Daimyojin deity which enshrined Sarutahiko no mikoto.

sen.j: 磐衝別命が亡くなった後にその子である磐城別命は磐衝別命を三尾山に葬り本神社を創建した。
sen.e: After Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto's death, his son, Iwakiwake no mikoto buried his father at Mount Mio, where he founded a main shrine.
After Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto's death, his son, Iwakiwake no mikoto buried his father at Mount Mio, where he founded a main shrine.
After Iwatsukiwake-no-Mikoto's death, his son, Iwakiwake no mikoto buried his father at Mt. Mio, where he founded a main shrine.

sen.j: 以後百年後、応神天皇の第11皇子速総別王も天成神道を学ぶため拜戸を訪れた。
sen.e: 100 years later from then, the 11th prince of Emperor Ojin, Hayabusawake no Miko also visited Haido to learn Amenaru-Michi.
100 years later, the 11th prince of Emperor Ojin, Hayabusawake no Miko also visited Haido to learn Amenaru-Michi.
100 years later, the 11th prince of Emperor Ojin, Hayabusawake no Miko also visited Haido to learn Amenaru-Michi.

sen.j: 速総別王の4世孫である彦主人王は、磐城別命の5世孫の振姫を越前國から迎えて妃とした。
sen.e: Hikoushio, the fourth grandchild of Hayabusawake no Miko, took Furihime, the fifth grandchild of Iwakiwake no mikoto, for the Empress from Echizen Province, who deliver triplets, Amanoatobeo, Oatobeo, and Oatobeo easily at haiden (a hall of worship) of the main shrine as ubuya (a hut for delivering babies).
sen.cmt: 天迹部王、男迹部王、太迹部王の正式な読みが不明です。（男迹部王、太迹部王の読みが同じものしか見つかりません。）
sen.e: Hikoushio, the fourth grandchild of Hayabusawake no Miko, took Furihime, the fifth grandchild of Iwakiwake no mikoto, for the Empress from Echizen Province, who delivered triplets, Amanoatobeo, Oatobeo, and Oatobeo easily at haiden (a hall of worship) of the main shrine as ubuya (a hut for delivering babies).
Hikoushio, a fourth generation descendant of Hayabusawake no Miko, took Furihime, the fifth generation descendant of Iwakiwake no mikoto, as an empress from Echizen Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理世孫の表記変更しました。

sen.j: 振姫は本社拝殿を産所として、天迹部王、男迹部王、太迹部王の3児を同時に安産した。
sen.e: Furihime delivered triplets, Amanoatobeo, Oatobeo and Oatobeo without any complications at a hall of worship of the main shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理産所として、というのは、ここで振姫が出産したということでわかるので、わざわざ訳出しませんでした。

sen.j: ちなみに男迹部王は、後の継体天皇である。
sen.e: For your information, Oatobeo became Emperor Keitai later.
As a side note, Oatobeo later became Emperor Keitai.
As a side note, Oatobeo later became Emperor Keitai.
